Author: Deleted User#0000
Content: To go back to your question :All nodes are on DCs , and some have weaker stats by far. In some cases it s just about server optim and good maintenance, but in other cases it s just because connectivity is not so good. There s no secret looking at stats : you can see day by day that there are patterns identified when you focus on regions

Author: blackjok3r#3181
Content: My node is also very old hardware, and in very isolated location , those two things don't go too nicly together. Optimization of software gave my node a chance but I chose to share my results with everyone else and lost the advantage gained, as I felt that was better for the network as a whole. I dont mind running election again next year, my node is able to maintain average performance in my region despite its old hardware and bad location. Still have plenty if resources for expansion as I am using 48 core quad CPU older server for the massive amount of ram available for much less upfront cost, although something faster can be rented elsewhere for less per month than I currently pay.

Author: Dr.Terminus#3269
Content: Good info

Author: Dr.Terminus#3269
Content: I don't want to come off as opportunistic simply electing to go with hosting provider for geolocation which is more advantageous for the server / me rather than selecting host which could be better for the network

Author: blackjok3r#3181
Content: I agree with that. For me I started with very little experience in all this, so purchased a cheap server upfront and built many nodes on it at home until I got it right, at the time that was my cheapest option, renting from a host for testnet wasn't something I could afford to do. Its all depends on what u can do. The best nodes are mostly dedicated servers owned by the operator, such as shossains and deckers. I think if mine was on the opposite aide of Australia, where most of the SH nodes are it would be much much better. Even with old hardware. I found disk speed and vast amounts of ram to be the highest requirement then number of CPU cores. The CPU speed per sore is less important, but affects restart times of daemons and as such gets up notarizing faster after updates, or if bad things happen resyncs of chains.

Author: Dr.Terminus#3269
Content: thing is I have hardware pretty close to being able to handle the load, would just need more RAM. It's my local bandwidth that can't cut it by 50%. Sucks. I'm off that though. Maybe in a few years one of my local providers will step it up

Author: blackjok3r#3181
Content: My server is using a gigabit local connection at DC but international bandwidth is about 100Mbit which is plenty really apart from the first sync of all the chains.
